post1.title: Uk Traffic.md
post1.content: Example Markdown Post . Basic setup . Jekyll requires blog post files to be named according to the following format: . YEAR-MONTH-DAY-filename.md . Where YEAR is a four-digit number, MONTH and DAY are both two-digit numbers, and filename is whatever file name you choose, to remind yourself what this post is about. .md is the file extension for markdown files. . The first line of the file should start with a single hash character, then a space, then your title. This is how you create a “level 1 heading” in markdown. Then you can create level 2, 3, etc headings as you wish but repeating the hash character, such as you see in the line ## File names above. . Basic formatting . You can use italics, bold, code font text, and create links. Here’s a footnote 1. Here’s a horizontal rule: . . Lists . Here’s a list: . item 1 | item 2 | . And a numbered list: . item 1 | item 2 | Boxes and stuff . This is a quotation . . You can include alert boxes …and… . . You can include info boxes Images . . Code . You can format text and code per usual . General preformatted text: . # Do a thing do_thing() . Python code and output: . # Prints '2' print(1+1) . 2 . Formatting text as shell commands: . echo "hello world" ./some_script.sh --option "value" wget https://example.com/cat_photo1.png . Formatting text as YAML: . key: value - another_key: "another value" . Tables . Column 1 Column 2 . A thing | Another thing | . Tweetcards . Altair 4.0 is released! https://t.co/PCyrIOTcvvTry it with: pip install -U altairThe full list of changes is at https://t.co/roXmzcsT58 ...read on for some highlights. pic.twitter.com/vWJ0ZveKbZ . — Jake VanderPlas (@jakevdp) December 11, 2019 Footnotes . [21:26] To [Uhls]: I’m jealous of a dog :P [21:27] [Uhls]: Yeah, I’d like to cuddle you [21:27] To [Uhls]: even needy girlfriend is shunning me! [22:04] To [Durden]: which flash, biastch? [22:04] To [Durden]: me type ood [22:04] [Durden]: 4th tab, centre-right: [Flask of Mighty Restoration] [22:08] To [Durden]: can you say binge eating? [22:08] [Durden]: binge eating [22:08] To [Durden]: I’m having a not good day apparently [22:08] To [Durden]: I’m also pretty drunk [22:09] To [Durden]: and typing good [22:09] [Durden]: I know [22:09] [Durden]: I love you <3 [22:09] To [Durden]: I love you <3 [22:09] To [Durden]: I’m sorry life gets at me sometimes [22:12] [Durden]: Do you have food? [22:12] To [Durden]: onl y3 [22:12] To [Durden]: 4 [22:13] To [Durden]: I can be crazy somet8imes! [22:13] To [Durden]: top right ;) [22:13] [Durden]: Not really [22:13] [Durden]: You do a great job, considering [22:13] To [Durden]: I mean i can, but then I think about it [22:13] To [Durden]: great job? [22:14] [Durden]: At handling the shit in your life [22:14] To [Durden]: apparently I’m strong and resilient [22:15] [Durden]: Muted [22:15] To [Durden]: probs for the best! as it’s what i have to tell gremlins for private time [22:16] To [Durden]: I just wish, at times, I didn’t have to be resilient. It’s tiring and I have had enough [22:34] [Durden]: What’s wrong, kitten? [22:36] To [Durden]: i just shouldn’t drink [22:36] [Durden]: I was gonna suggest water [22:36] [Durden]: But you didn’t answer [22:37] To [Durden]: I’m just sad and I don’t lik being called crazy. I try really hard and I’m sick of trying [22:37] [Durden]: You’re aware I didn’t really call you crazy [22:38] To [Durden]: you did [22:38] [Durden]: I made a joke, I wasn’t calling you crazy [22:38] To [Durden]: you made it repeatedly [22:40] [Durden]: I made a joke about top-right and you dug in [22:41] To [Durden]: no, you doubled down with several comments [22:42] [Durden]: If that’s how you see it, maybe I shouldn’t talk to you when you’re drinking, or stop making jokes [22:43] To [Durden]: “I’ve dated someone bottom right” “you’re not a unicorn” further comments aren’t my “how I see it” [22:44] To [Durden]: so sdon’t “that’s your opinion me! [23:17] To [Durden]: thanks for fucking off when i needed some support/reassurance [23:17] [Durden]: You were attacking me [23:17] To [Durden]: no I was stating what you’d said [23:18] [Durden]: You were misinterpreting what I said [23:18] To [Durden]: so say that [23:18] [Durden]: I’m not talking about this tonight [23:18] To [Durden]: yeah, thanks [23:47] [Durden]: I feel like I do enough to support you, but I’m not obliged to feel attacked when I’m trying to explain and you’re not listening. You made me pretty angry, so it’s best we don’t talk for the evening. [23:47] [Durden]: when I* [23:53] To [Durden]: I’ve never said you’d not done enough. If saying what you said that upset me, makes you angry then that’s your prerogative. Just know, blanking me and stating you won’tspeak to me, instead of saying you’re angry, will never bode well with me [23:53] [Durden]: I tried explaining my perspective [23:53] To [Durden]: no, you didn’t [23:53] [Durden]: I disagree [23:55] To [Durden]: Then disagree [23:56] To [Durden]: I don’t have the energy to argue or articulate a point, I’m sorry you’re angry. . This is the footnote. ↩ . |

post4.title: An Example Markdown Post
post4.content: Example Markdown Post . Basic setup . Jekyll requires blog post files to be named according to the following format: . YEAR-MONTH-DAY-filename.md . Where YEAR is a four-digit number, MONTH and DAY are both two-digit numbers, and filename is whatever file name you choose, to remind yourself what this post is about. .md is the file extension for markdown files. . The first line of the file should start with a single hash character, then a space, then your title. This is how you create a “level 1 heading” in markdown. Then you can create level 2, 3, etc headings as you wish but repeating the hash character, such as you see in the line ## File names above. . Basic formatting . You can use italics, bold, code font text, and create links. Here’s a footnote 1. Here’s a horizontal rule: . . Lists . Here’s a list: . item 1 | item 2 | . And a numbered list: . item 1 | item 2 | Boxes and stuff . This is a quotation . . You can include alert boxes …and… . . You can include info boxes Images . . Code . You can format text and code per usual . General preformatted text: . # Do a thing do_thing() . Python code and output: . # Prints '2' print(1+1) . 2 . Formatting text as shell commands: . echo "hello world" ./some_script.sh --option "value" wget https://example.com/cat_photo1.png . Formatting text as YAML: . key: value - another_key: "another value" . Tables . Column 1 Column 2 . A thing | Another thing | . Tweetcards . page1.title: About Me
page1.content: Accomplishing my PhD in Chemical Physics sparked a passion for data and analysis. After a long fought battle in the gas kinetics laboratory - to gather said data - I carried out computational modelling and statistical analysis to obtain rate coefficients. The resulting knowledge enabled understanding of the behaviour of magnesium atoms and ions in the upper atmospheres of Earth and Mars. This knowledge was utilised in atmospheric models, which explained behaviour discovered via satellite observations and has led to several journal publications[LINK] and international presentations. . During a career break, to raise a family, I turned this enthusiasm towards building and bolstering the skills necessary to establish a career in data analytics. I have gained aptitude in Python (notable libraries: Pandas, NumPy, SciKit-Learn, Matplotlib and Seaborn), SQL and Tableau; and have utilised these skills in various projects, as evidenced in my portfolio [LINK]. . I am a highly motivated, organised and analytically minded problem solver who has used the skill s obtained during my education, employment and career break to push forward with a career path I am eager to follow. My abilities are well-rounded, including excellent written and verbal communication skills, gained through publications in academic journals and presentations to audiences of varying expertise and background. . Being self-motivated and ambitious, I am committed to forging ahead with a data analytics career. You can contact me on lottes.salter@gmail.com. .
